channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Italian Praised for Saving Jews Is Now Seen as Nazi Collaborator
item.description: Information about Giovanni Palatucci, celebrated for saving Jews, is being removed from the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in light of evidence that the tales may be untrue.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA COHEN

item.title: Extremism Rises Among Myanmar Buddhists Wary of Muslim Minority
item.description: Amid hate-filled speeches and violence, a nationwide fundamentalist movement has grown with an agenda that now includes boycotts of Muslim-made goods.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashin Wirathu, the spiritual leader of the radical movement, skates a thin line between free speech and incitement, taking advantage of the new freedoms at a fragile time of transition.

item.title: India Ink: Thousands Are Stranded in Northern India Flooding
item.description: The death toll from flash floods in northern India rose to more than 150 on Thursday, with 50,000 Hindu pilgrims still stranded in the mountainous state of Uttarakhand.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Rescued pilgrims met their family members after arriving in Dehradun, Uttarakhand, on Wednesday.

item.title: Turkish Liberals Turn Their Backs on Erdogan
item.description: For an urban elite, including some protesters, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s response to demonstrations has led to a final break that began with his intimidation of the news media.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former supporters of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan say his response to the Taksim Square protests was the final straw.

item.title: At the Taliban Office, Waiting for Progress
item.description: With both Afghan and American delegates delaying travel to Qatar for the start of talks, the insurgents face pressure to comply with Afghan demands.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Brazil’s Leftist Ruling Party, Born of Protests, Is Perplexed by Revolt
item.description: The governing Workers Party is watching with dismay as Brazil’s largest city braces for a new round of demonstrations on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: The Lede: Tear Gas Fired Outside Stadium in Brazil, But Protest Still Spreads Inside
item.description: The police in the northeastern city of Fortaleza fired tear gas and rubber bullets at an estimated 35,000 protesters, whose message was echoed by people inside the stadium and even some players.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Chancellor Merkel Discovers the Internet
item.description: Germany’s Angela Merkel has been unmercifully mocked for suggesting that the Internet is uncharted territory. Is she really out of touch, or was she just reflecting her suspicions about the perils of the technology?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Chancellor Merkel examined a tablet computer at a Hannover trade fair in March.

item.title: Way of the World: The Problem With Too Many Millionaires
item.description: Winner-take-all forces are driving an extreme concentration of wealth at the top, with the ranks of the ultrarich, people with investable assets of at least $30 million, surging 11 percent over the past year.
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: India Ink: Amartya Sen on Why India Trails China
item.description: The provision of essential services to its population is where India lags the most behind China argues Amartya Sen, a Nobel laureate and a professor of economics and philosophy at Harvard University.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: 27 Million People Said to Live in ‘Modern Slavery’
item.description: A new report by the U.S. State Department says as many as 27 million people live in modern slavery, and more needs to be done to counter this cruel exploitation and violation of human dignity.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry presents Laura Anyola Tufon of Cameroon with a Trafficking in Persons Heroes' award at an event releasing this year's human trafficking report.

item.title: Pollution in Singapore Hits Record Level
item.description: Officials said the illegal burning of forestland to clear ground for new plantings in Indonesia had created the stubborn haze enveloping Singapore.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Singpore's business district on Thursday evening after the city-state's pollution index reached a record level.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: And the Weatherman Says There’s More to Come
item.description: Europe has been enduring another year of unseasonable weather, and climate scientists warn that the pattern of extended winters and wet summers could last for years. Is it a natural phenomenon or does man-made climate change play a part?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Sandor H. Szabo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Flooding in Hungary this month was one manifestation of unusual weather patterns.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 20
item.description: Silicon Valley and the U.S. government converge; unemployment in the Philippines; success for HPV vaccine; James Gandolfini dies; and modest goals for Tahiti’s soccer team.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: President Obama with Chancellor Angela Merkel and Berlin's mayor, Klaus Wowereit, at Brandenburg Gate on Wednesday.

item.title: Detention Deaths in Chinese Corruption Cases Raise Concern
item.description: At least three officials caught up in a crackdown on official corruption in the last three months have died while in secretive Communist Party detention centers.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: India Ink: Judge’s Remarks on Premarital Sex Raise Questions in India
item.description: The Madras High Court ordered a man to pay spousal support to his live-in partner of five years, who is also the mother of his children.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: A couple at a sea front off the coast of Arabian Sea in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Friday.

item.title: Senate Confirms Economic Adviser as Trade Representative
item.description: Michael Froman, currently a senior White House economic adviser, will lead an agency involved in two significant trade deals.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: British Court Rules Against Sanctions on Iranian Bank
item.description: The decision raised new questions about the country’s secret courts and was a vindication for the Iranian bank, Bank Mellat, which had spent four years fighting the sanctions designation.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo’s First Envoy to Serbia Resigns After Two Days
item.description: Serbia and its former southern province exchanged official representatives on Monday under a push by the European Union to improve ties between the Balkan neighbors.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Muslim Women Sentenced to Hard Labor in Myanmar
item.description: A court found the women guilty of setting off a recent outbreak of sectarian violence and convicted them of “insulting religion.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Quest for Sainthood for John Paul II Said to Advance
item.description: A Vatican official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said a commission of theologians approved a miracle attributed to John Paul’s intercession.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Brazil’s Leftist Ruling Party, Born of Protests, Is Perplexed by Revolt
item.description: The governing Workers Party is watching with dismay as political corruption, bad public services and the government’s focus on lifting Brazil’s international stature through events like the 2014 World Cup and the 2016 Olympics inspire outrage.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: While Claiming Battle Gains Against Rebels, Syria’s Assad Is Facing Currency Crisis
item.description: The Syrian pound fell 30 percent against the dollar over the weekend in panicky selling by Syrians worried it could weaken even further.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why India Trails China
item.description: A great gap between India and China is in the provision of essential public services — a failing that depresses living standards and is a persistent drag on growth.
item.dc:creator: By AMARTYA SEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Lebanon, Overrun by Syrian Refugees
item.description: A humanitarian crisis is threatening the region’s stability.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NINETTE KELLEY
